results.title: Mathematics peep show
results.creator_credit: IBM, Charles Eames and Ray Eames
results.brief_description: A collection of five films, each presenting a mathematical idea. The film was part of the exhibition ‘Mathematica: a world of numbers and beyond’. The two minute vignettes use a combination of animation, live action and photographic techniques to present five mathematic principles. They are: ERATOSTHENES; TOPOLOGY: JORDAN’S CURVE THEORY; SYMMETRY; SOMETHING ABOUT FUNCTIONS; 2N: A STORY ABOUT THE POWER OF NUMBER. Drawings by Glen Fleck, music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Mathematics of the honeycomb
results.creator_credit: Moody Institute of Science. Educational Film Division
results.brief_description: Explains the place of mathematics in engineering and the sciences as evidenced by the application of modern mathematical methods to the honeycomb problem. Includes close-up scenes of bees exuding and manipulating wax.

results.title: Mathematics at your fingertips
results.brief_description: In today’s classrooms various new ways are being tried to put children more at ease with numbers. This film sows one of them - a system developed by a Belgian schoolmaster, Georges Cuisenaire, who made sets of coloured sticks carefully designed to help children grasp simple mathematical relationships. As his method is demonstrated in a Montreal classroom we see how children ‘get the feel’ of numbers right from the start and advance confidently from the concrete to the abstract mathematical concepts. With children of StGeorges School, Montreal.

results.title: Mathematics - a foundation course: groups 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Open University, BBC-TV and Robert Clamp
results.brief_description: Mathematical meaning of the term “group”, basic requirements, by inter-changing spheres in two different arrangements we can arrive at the same group, (klein 4), symmetry throughout history, predicting vibrations of water molecules.

results.title: Matewan
results.creator_credit: Goldcrest, Red Dog Films, Peggy Rajski, Maggie Renzi and John Sayles
results.brief_description: A realistic account of the fierce struggle that raged in the coalfields of West Virginia in the 1920’s between coalminers, fighting for trade-union rights, and mine-owners who employed gangster methods to maintain crippling conditions and pay. Features photography by Haskell Wexler.

results.title: Mates, martyrs and masters
results.creator_credit: Seven Dimensions, Eve Ash and Ted Robinson
results.brief_description: A training film aimed at developing management skills. Tom, the “Mate” has difficulty accepting leadership responsibilities and fails to provide firmness and direction to his work group. Harriet, the “Martyr” is constantly snowed under with work because she is disorganised and fails to delegate work to her staff. Rick, the “Master” avoids risks for fear of making mistakes. Dr. Warren Burrows, Motivation Specialist, assists in examining and improving their management skills. Made in association with the Victorian Film Corporation and the Australian Film Commission.

results.title: Maternal deprivation in young children
results.creator_credit: New York University. Film Library, Institut National d'Hygiene and Genevieve Appell
results.brief_description: Part of the record collected by a French research unit studying the effects of mernal deprivation in young children. Those studied are between one and two-and-a-half years old. All had been reared in institutions where because of impersonal care they had become seriously impaired in the capacity for human relationship. The film shows the disorders that appear and the subsequent progress of the children under psychotherapy. A study carried out by a French research unit directed by Jenny Rondinesco.

results.title: Materials handling methods
results.brief_description: Shows methods of handling materials in large warehouses and unloading bulky equipment. Illustrates the special applications of two-wheel trucks, four-wheel trucks, dolly trucks, hand-lift trucks, fork lifts, tractor trailers, belt conveyors and straddle trucks.

results.title: Material unaccounted for
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Week”.
Investigates the security of the nuclear plant at which Karen Silkwood worked before her mysterious death. Radioactive material had been placed in Ms. Silkwood’s home during the period in which she was campaigning against the working conditions and safety measures at the U.S. American plant.

group_siblings.title: Forum of protest
group_siblings.creator_credit: HSV7 Melbourne, Richard Linning and Gary Cunningham

results.title: Material matters
results.creator_credit: Anvil Films, British Productivity Council, Ralph May, R I C H Warren and Sydney Sharples
results.brief_description: Britain’s economy today rests largely upon its manufacturing industries. It is therefore essential that maximum use be made of local and imported raw materials. In Britain, waste causes a loss of hundreds of millions of pounds each year. Coal is the most wasted commodity of all - inefficient boilers, factory equipment and old-fashioned household grates waste as much as half the total coal produced in Britain each year. Within ten years, at this rate, Britain could not maintain enough coal supplies to meet the demand. Factories must keep down to a minimum the number of waste articles, for instance, there is more often than not unnecessary waste from both metal and plastic pressing, spray-painting etc. More economical and time-saving methods are required in the manufacture of parts. The film draws attention to the small innocuous wastes which usually go unnoticed. It is these wastes that add up to a national bill which Britain cannot afford.
